passages.text: Capital Compounder at a Discount; initiate at Buy

We initiate coverage of Brookfield Corporation ("BN") with a Buy rating, with a \(78 12\) - month price target, \(\sim 20\%\) upside. In our view, BN combines the scale and stability of a global, diversified balance sheet of assets with the expertise from its \(73\%\) - ownership in Brookfield Asset Management ("BAM"). The aggregate Brookfield ecosystem oversees nearly \(\) 1\(tr of assets spanning real estate, infrastructure, renewable energy, private equity, private credit, and insurance solutions. We view BN as a capital compounder that is on the cusp of seeing a significant step - up in excess capital generation, resulting in faster book value growth, higher ROE and a greater return of capital (share repurchases) opportunities. This will be supported by (1) Improving cash flow dynamics in the Real Estate business - the biggest source of BN's enterprise value discount; (2) Step - up in Carried interest/ Performance fees; and (3) Steady growth in Insurance amid several business model advantages. Our bottom - up analysis of BN's capital sources and uses suggests that the firm's cumulative net capital generation will step up to an estimated \(\sim\)\)11bn 2025E- 2027E up from \(\sim\)\)3bn in 2023- 2024, with at least half of this excess capital to go toward share repurchases ( \(\sim 50\%\) of excess, consistent with the pace of deployment towards buybacks in the prior two - year period).
We estimate the firm's DE/share of \(\) 3.90/\(\) 4.50/\(\) 5.73 - a 13\% \(CAGR through 2027\) \uparrow \(with firm - wide ROE reaching 17\% in 2027, up from \~15\% current\) \uparrow\$

BN is currently trading at 14.5X on 2026 DE - a discount to other capital- heavy Alternative Managers (KKR and APO) at 20X. On a Price- to- Book basis, BN is trading at 2.3X P/B - also a discount to APO and KKR's 3.3X multiple. We initiate coverage of Brookfield Corporate ("BN") with a Buy rating, and a \(78 12\) - month price target implying \(\sim 20\%\) upside to current levels. We view BN as a capital compounder that is on the cusp of seeing a significant step- up in excess capital generation, resulting in faster book value growth, higher ROE and a greater return of capital (share repurchases) opportunities. We expect the firm's increasing capital generation to be supported by (1) Improving cash flow dynamics in the Real Estate business - the biggest source of BN's enterprise value discount, in our view; (2) Step- up in Carried interest/ Performance fees; and (3) Steady growth in Insurance amid several business model advantages.

Our bottom- up analysis of BN's capital sources and uses suggests that the firm's cumulative net capital generation will step up to an estimated \(\sim \$ 11bn\) 2025E- 2027E up from \(\sim \$ 3bn\) in 2023- 2024. We expect at least half of this excess capital generation to be used toward share repurchases, resulting in at least a \(5\%\) reduction in the firm's sharecount, with the remainder being used for incremental acquisitions (including in the Insurance space) to drive higher returns overtime.

BN is currently trading at 14.5X on 2026 DE - a discount to other capital- heavy Alternative Managers (KKR and APO) at 20X. On a Price- to- Book basis, BN is trading at 2.3X P/B - also a discount to APO's and KKR's 3.3X multiple. While some of the discount is warranted, we believe that BN's improving capital generation and higher ROE will help narrow the gap with its closest Alt Manager peers. Given the "conglomerate" nature of BN's business, we use a two- pronged approach to value the stock with a 50/50 blend of a SOTP- based analysis, as well as an ROE- derived P/B multiples analysis. Our 12- month target price of \(78 implies a 2026E P/DE multiple of 17.3X and a 2026 P/B of 2.6X.\)

1. Continued growth at BAM: BN's \(73\%\) ownership of BAM is a stable and growing source of cash earnings; we are Buy-Rated on shares of BAM with a \(66 12\) -month target price. BAM benefits the broader Brookfield ecosystem, generating fee revenue from the BN-affiliated vehicles on the BN balance sheet and managing BN's Insurance assets. The symbiotic relationship between the two companies creates a stable base of permanent capital for BAM shareholders, and BAM provides a capital-light source of cash earnings to BN. BAM's exposure to secular growth areas (particularly in Energy Transition / Renewable Energy, Infrastructure, and Credit, with prospects of expanding into AI / Data Center infra) is critical to its fundraising success which has enabled the third-party investor business to reach critical scale.
We continue to see an increasing breadth of fundraising sources as supporting our \(\sim 15\%\) fee- related earnings / share (FRE / share) CAGR through 2027 for shares of BAM.

2. Steady growth from BN's expanding Insurance business: We expect Insurance (BWS) to remain a key strategy growth area for BN. BWS is a scaled player in the insurance space with \(\) 102bn\(in net reserves - primarily concentrated in Fixed Annuities ( \sim 80\% of the book). We expect the business to grow assets at \sim 14\% CAGR through 2027 with \sim 10\% (net) annualized organic growth via continued market share gains in the US retail annuities channel, expansion into U.S. and non-U.S. PRT (Pension Risk Transfer) market, and through funding agreement issuance. Management is targeting a 15\% ROE for the business, though we think industry spread compression and lower U.S. policy rates pose a modest risk to these targets (we model net spread in the 160-170bps range vs. management's \sim 180-200bps target). That said, we think BWS comes with several unique attributes including: (1) Greater exposure to Alternative investments, leveraging BAM's expertise and allowing the firm to earn premium investment rates; (2) Relatively lower leverage and meaningful amount of excess capital vs. peers; and (3) Global footprint and scale with large financial institutions, enabling the firm to accelerate its pace of sales. Combined, we think BWS can sustain \sim 14\%-15\% ROE through 2027 (a bit lower than management's 15\% target), with a 14\% CAGR in distributable earnings. Importantly, we expect BWS to essentially self-fund its growth, creating more fee-paying AUM to BAM (and therefore BN), without consuming incremental capital from the Hold Co.

3. Real Estate nearing an inflection point: BN's large Real Estate portfolio is currently generating negative "operating FFO" or funds from operation. At BPG (the Core + Transitional & Development Real Estate assets that sit directly on the BN balance sheet), \(\sim 60\%\) of total debt is floating rate. With policy rates expected to move lower over the next few years (based on market forward curve), we expect positive operating cash flow by 2026, even without relying on incremental property sales. Although the public cap rate implies a \(40\% -60\%\) value discount to BN's current Real Estate carrying value, our SOTP analysis shows that BN's market cap implies a negative value of BN's real estate equity ownership (of approximately \(-\) 4bn), which we think is too punitive even under more conservative cap rate assumptions. We expect that property sales, de-leveraging and stronger FFO over the coming years will help narrow the gap between the market's currently ascribed negative value to BN's real estate portfolio and values implied by current cap rates.

4. Carried Interest to meaningfully step-up: BN estimates \(\) 3.5bn\(of net realized carried interest over the next three years, supported by our bottoms - up, fund - by - fund analysis of net accrued carry that sits on BN's balance sheet. Over the prior two years, \sim\) 1.2b of carried interest was realized. We expect a meaningful step up starting in 2026E, and another leg of growth in 2027 as \sim 2020 - era vintages start to mature. We estimate\) \ \(5.3bn\) of realized gross carried interest through 2027E, with \(\) 3.3bn\(of net carried interest attributable to BN.\)

Brookfield Corporation ("BN") is a diversified holding company with four primary economic engines: (A) Asset Management: a controlling \((73\%)\) stake in Brookfield Asset Management ("BAM"), a leading publicly traded alternative asset manager; in addition to receiving pro- rate share of BAM's earnings, BN is also entitled to a material share of carried interest from BAM- managed funds, including legacy pre- spin vintages where BN retains \(100\%\) of gross carry pre- compensation; (B) Insurance Operations, Brookfield Wealth Solutions ("BWS"): a wholly owned insurance platform focused on originating Fixed Annuities, Pension Risk Transfer and Funding Agreements; (C) Real Estate: a large, directly owned portfolio of Real Estate assets globally, as well as stakes in BAM- managed opportunistic real estate funds; and (D) Listed affiliates: economic interests in publicly traded vehicles BIP (infrastructure), BEP (renewables), and BBU (private equity/industrial).

The firm's Asset Management capabilities sit at the center of the overarching Brookfield ecosystem. BN is the parent and controlling shareholder of several products including the firm's on- balance sheet real estate portfolio, BWS, and listed affiliates (BIP, BEP, BBU) that all pay management fees to BAM. As a result, BN is simultaneously a GP ("BAM") and a LP (BN B/S) across the alternative asset class spectrum.
Specifically, the business is comprised of:

Asset Management: With \(\) 563bn\(in Fee - bearing Capital, BAM is one of the largest global Alternative Asset Managers with expertise across Credit (45% of Fee - paying AUM), Real Estate (18%), Infra, Renewables/Transition (29%), and Private Equity (8%). BAM earns a management fee and incentive fees from third - party LP's (clients) as well as from entities affiliated with/controlled by BN, including the listed YieldCo's (Listed Affiliates), as well as the legacy BPG portfolio in Real Estate. These vehicles alone generated \(27\%\) of BAM's TTM fee- related revenues. Another \(\sim 5\%\) of BAM's fee revenues come from managing BWS's Insurance investment portfolio, resulting in \(\sim 30\%\) of BAM's fee related revenues coming from BN affiliated entities.

Carried Interest: When BAM spun- out from BN, BN retained its equity ownership in legacy accrued carried interest - specifically, the firm owns \(100\%\) of the carry generated by pre- spin out funds that are closer to maturity. BN will also get \(33\%\) of carried interest on all future vintage, with the balance attributable to BAM. Currently, BAM does not expect any carried interest until \(\sim 2027\) . At BN, carried interest was \(\sim\) 500mn of TTM earnings, or \(7\%\) of the total, and management expects \(\) 3.3bn\(over the next three years.

BIP, BEP, BBU - the Listed Affiliates: Each of BIP (infra), BEP (renewables), and BBU (PE), is a publicly traded YieldCo, listed on exchanges in both the U.S. and in Canada. Each is an LP that invests in and alongside BAM- managed drawdown funds and strategies. These platforms were initially incubated by BN as owner/operator and were subsequently listed over time. At BN's share of each vehicle's public market cap, the aggregate equity in these businesses was \(\) 17.1bn\(or \sim 17\%\) of BN's

As publicly traded YieldCo's these vehicles distribute substantially all of their cash flow to investors as dividends; as the largest shareholder in each YieldCo, BN itself receives these dividends at its pro rata ownership share on its income statement. These dividends amounted to \(\) 815\mathrm{m}\$ over the TTM period (12% of gross earnings).

Direct Investments: BN also holds direct stakes in BAM- managed funds outside of the listed vehicles, called "Direct Investments" in the firm's reporting. Roughly half of this bucket is Opportunistic Real Estate funds (BSREP) managed by BAM, with the balance in Private Equity, Infrastructure, Credit, and other various co- investments. As of 2Q25, these investments were marked at \(\) 11.9\mathrm{bn}\(Fair Value), accounting for\)9\%\$ of BN's balance sheet. Management plans to let portions of these stakes roll off as vintages are harvested. There are currently - \(\) 4\mathrm{bn}\$ of unfunded commitments that BN has made to additional BAM- managed investments, which BN will fund as those funds deploy capital, but ultimately the firm targets a downsizing of the portfolio to - \(\) 8\mathrm{bn}\$ from the nearly \(\) 12\mathrm{bn}\$ today by 2029. BN reports the cash distributions it receives from these funds in its earnings - \(\) 906\mathrm{m}\$ on a TTM basis as of 2Q25, or 14% of total BN earnings.

Real Estate: The vast majority of BN's Real Estate portfolio is legacy "BPG"/"BPY"- a vehicle that used to be one of the firm's listed partnerships; BN privatized the fund in 2021 amid rising interest expense weighing on net earnings, taking \(100\%\) of the portfolio onto its balance sheet. Like the other listed partnerships, this vehicle was a combination of LP stakes in BAM- managed drawdown funds (about 1/3), and also a portfolio of individual properties ( \(\sim 2 / 3\) of total legacy BPG investments). Today, BN reports the drawdown fund component of the BPG portfolio in the "Direct Investments" segment as noted above. The individual properties are still referred to as "BPG", reported in BN's Real Estate segment. Today, BPG is \(\) 24.5\mathrm{bn}\$ of equity value on BN's balance sheet - \(18\%\) of the total. In aggregate, Real Estate earnings were \(\) 872\mathrm{m}\$ on a TTM basis, or \(13\%\) of BN's total. Note, Real Estate earnings are reported as distributions from the Real Estate sub up to BN, though these distributions are not currently covered by BPG's FFO.

BWS - Insurance: The alternative asset manager / insurance company tie up is a structure first pioneered by Apollo/Athene, with many other players pursuing versions of the same strategy. BN's invested capital in the \(100\%\) owned business is \(\) 11.6\mathrm{bn}\$ or \(8\%\) of the firm's balance sheet. BN has quickly scaled its insurance business via acquisition (acquiring both American National and AEL since 2022) - mostly specializing in fixed annuities. Annuity liabilities match well with BAM / BN's expertise in infrastructure, real estate, energy transition, and private credit, which offer long- duration, yield- oriented assets suitable for insurers' asset- liability management. The large ( \(>\) 100bn) and growing investment portfolio provides another source of permanent capital with consistent stream of net inflows (target of \(>\) 20bn gross annual flows, \(\sim\) 10bn on net basis \(= 10\%\) net new asset growth rate) for the entity to invest. Insurance earnings today account for \(\sim 25\%\) of total BN earnings on a TTM basis, or \(\) 1.6\mathrm{bn}\$ .

We view BN as a multi- year capital compounder that is on the cusp of seeing a significant step- up in net capital generation, which will result in faster book value growth, higher ROE and a greater return of capital (share repurchases) opportunities. Specifically, we expect BN's cumulative net capital generation (after taking into account uses of capital of capital) to step up to an estimated \(\sim \$ 11bn\) 2025E- 2027E up from \(\sim \$ 3bn\) in 2023- 2024. The largest sources of improvement are expected to come from (1) Improvement in BN's Real Estate's portfolio's cash flows; (2) A material increase in performance fees/carried interest - importantly these cash flows do not have significant "capital uses"; (3) Improving monetization backdrop driving higher disposition activity; and (4) Steady growth at BAM - BN's Asset Management business which also does not consume much growth capital at BN level. We also expect BN's Insurance business (BWS) to self- fund. We expect at least half of net capital generation to be used toward share repurchases, resulting in at least a \(5\%\) reduction in the firm's sharecount, with the remainder being used for incremental acquisitions (including in the Insurance space) to drive higher returns overtime.

Our analysis considered Sources of Capital / Capital Generation and Uses of Capital / Capital Utilization across BN's businesses. For the most part, BN's sources of capital are captured within the firm's DE (Distributable Earnings) primary reported metric - which mostly consists of cash- based earnings. We make to main adjustment to DE including:

Real Estate Recurring Cash flows: When BPG was privatized, BN decomposed the business into two buckets: (1) BSREP stakes and (2) individual properties, (Core + T&D). The legacy BPG business was paying a dividend to BN when it was a listed entity, and that dividend continues (flat, unchanged) to this day at \(100\%\) ownership now that the business is private and sits wholly on the BN balance sheet. The Core + T&D portion pays a \(500mn annual dividend to BN. When we isolate cash flows from the Core and T&D portfolio, however, we see the business is generating negative net cash flows as multiple years of challenged monetization backdrop and higher interest expense has required BN to inject equity to sustain the distribution. In our adjusted framework, we remove the\) 500mn dividend and instead show the operating FFO of the directly owned investment properties (representing net cash flows after interest expense / G&A expense). This is how we bridge to Recurring Cash DE (GSe). With the underlying cash flows (FFO) of BN's real estate portfolio improving amid lower rates and lower leverage, we expect the business will become less of a drag on net capital generation.

Real Estate Dispositions: Additionally, given that the proceeds from dispositions are a source of capital that firm will use to allocate towards growth, we add the actual cash flows from dispositions from a BSREP monetization event (like any other LP in the fund would), and when directly owned properties are sold. The proceeds from disposition activity are not shown in BN's reported Distributable Earnings, given that the value of the asset is already accounted for the on balance sheet; we believe these proceeds are worth tracking as they are ultimately a source of BN's capital allocation plans. Our Recurring Cash DE plus proceeds from dispositions are
essentially BN's Gross Cash Flows, which represents the pool of cash that BN can use to reinvest or distribute out. The details of this bridge are shown in Exhibit 10 and Exhibit 11.

In terms of uses of cash, we expect BN's capital needs to be driven by: (1) reinvesting in BAM- managed drawdown funds / funding seed stakes in new strategies; (2) recycling \(100\%\) of Insurance earnings back into the business to support insurance balance sheet growth; (3) paying down debt at BPG.

Between 2023 and 2024, the firm generated \(\) 13bn\(of Gross Cash Flows (\) \ \(8bn\) of DE + \(\) 5bn\(of proceeds from disposition). Roughly\) 50\% \(of that gross cash flow was allocated to stakes in BAM - managed drawdown funds, or else used to seed new vehicles at BAM. Additionally, the firm paid down corporate debt at its BPG Real Estate portfolio, and invested\) \ \(2bn\) invested in growing the Insurance business (excluding the acquisition of AEL). After accounting for the firm's dividend ( \(\) 1.0bn\(over that period), the result was\) \ \(3bn\) of net funds after reinvestment, and BN used \(\sim 50\%\) of that ( \(\) 1.6bn\(to repurchase shares over that period (historical shown in Exhibit 14).

Currently, BN plans on letting its stakes in BAM- managed drawdown funds roll off; the current stack of investments is \(>\) 11bn on the BN balance sheet, and the firm is targeting a "right- sized" \(\) 8bn\(portfolio by 2029. We know that BN has\) \sim \ \(4bn\) of outstanding but unfunded commitments to BAM- managed funds, that it will deploy as those funds are invested; this implies meaningful net cash generation as these funds roll off, above and beyond what BN will "re- invest". Additionally, we believe BN's Real Estate portfolio will be increasingly become "self- funded" as lower rates meaningfully bolster cash flows, obviating the need for BN to inject equity (see Real Estate section of report for full details).

Combined, we estimate \(\) 11bn\(of Funds Available for Return through 2027E (Exhibit 13). Like in the prior two years, we believe that\) >50\% \(, or\) \ \(6.2bn\) of those funds will be allocated to share repurchases through 2027E.

We see BN's Real Estate portfolio normalization as key to unlocking BN's shareholder value. For context, BN's balance sheet houses \(\sim \$ 31bn\) in Real Estate assets, including a \(25bn portfolio of direct investment properties as well as \~\) 6.5bn worth of stakes in BAM- managed BSREP funds (opportunistic real estate drawdown funds). The portfolio was largely a function of a take- private transaction in mid- 2021 when Brookfield acquired its publicly traded RE holding company, BPY (a.k.a BPG). While the portfolio accounts for \(>30\%\) of headline Distributable Earnings (reported as distributions from the Real Estate portfolio up to the Parent Company/BN), underlying cash flow metrics of the Real Estate portfolio have been weak, with FFO (before asset dispositions) not covering the distribution to BN. This has mostly been a function of high leverage levels and pressure from interest expense (even though underlying operating portfolio characteristics have been relatively steady). That said, we see prospects of lower interest rates (60% of BN's Real Estate portfolio is floating), healthy property- level performance across the majority of the book, and easing capital market conditions for real estate assets/asset sales driving meaningful improvement in cash flows / FFO of this business, which we think is not currently captured in the implied value of BN's Real Estate portfolio. Although the public cap rate implies a \(40\% - 60\%\) value discount to BN's current Real Estate carrying value, our SOTP analysis shows that BN's market cap implies a negative value of BN's real estate equity ownership (of approximately - \$4bn), which we think is too punitive even under more conservative cap rate assumptions. We expect that property sales, de- leveraging and stronger FFO over the coming years will help narrow the gap between the market's currently ascribed negative value to BN's real estate portfolio and values implied by current cap rates.
In this section, we outline:
Overview of the Real Estate portfolio: BN's \(31bn equity investments in real estate consists of three buckets:

Core portfolio (\$14.9bn equity carrying value or \(48\%\) of total) is a combination of "Class A" Office and Retail properties with strong underlying fundamentals; most of these are properties that Brookfield will not sell, with only modest planned dispositions across the portfolio by 2029 in BN's target plan. These are staple, anchor properties in large markets (NYC's Brookfield Place and One Manhattan West, Canary Wharf in the U.K., etc.).  - Transitional & Development, or "T&D" portfolio (\$9.6bn equity carrying value or \(31\%\) of total), which consists of lower quality Office and Retail assets ("fix and sell" strategy) most of which BN intends to sell overtime - with the majority expected to be sold by 2029. The T&D business also consists of BN's \$2.2bn North American residential development business.

BSREP funds (\$6.7bn equity carrying value or \(21\%\) ) where BN is a LP in its drawdown real estate funds. The funds are relatively diversified, with limited overlap between the funds' holdings and BN's Core and T&D portfolios.

- Leverage: BN's Real Estate portfolio comes with a considerable amount of leverage including \(\sim \$ 10bn\) of corporate level debt supporting \(\$ 24bn\) in Core and T&D equity (at stated values), with the underlying assets in these portfolios at about \(50\%\) LTV (also at stated equity values).

Scenario analysis assessing market implied fair value of the portfolio based on public comps: We use a combination of legacy BPG public filings as well as BN disclosures to compare the portfolio to that of publicly traded REIT peers. In the Core portfolio, BPG has peer-leading occupancy trends ( \(\sim 98\%\) in Retail vs \(96\%\) REIT avg; \(94\%\) in Office vs. REITs in mid- \(80\%\) ) and same- store NOI growth ( \(4\%\) in Core Office portfolio, vs. \(45\%\) below its carrying value or about \(13bn\) (vs. reported equity of \(25bn\) ). While this is clearly a significant delta, we believe the market implied discount embedded in BN's market cap is significantly more punitive even relative to this conservative scenario. Based on a SOTP analysis, we think BN's current market cap implies - \(4bn\) value. As BN sells down assets, de-levers and sees improvement in FFO, we see meaningful runway for this valuation gap to narrow.

Cash flow profile of the underlying properties and our expectations for FFO improvement: The standalone BPG business has been generating negative cash flow since before 2023, and has not covered the cash earnings that it pays to BN each quarter. BPG generated - \(187mn\) in cash flow (FFO) during 2024 vs. the \(500mn\) annual dividend to BN. Interest expense is currently the biggest drag on cash flows at BPG, but with \(60\%\) of total debt floating rate, we believe the portfolio will begin generating positive FFO by 2026 as rates come in. Since 2023, BN has injected \(>3bn\) of capital into BPG, accounting for \(>20\%\) of its total earnings over that period. In 2Q25, the business flipped into positive territory (albeit only \(+5mn\) of positive FFO), and we forecast - \(74mn\) in 2025E, and \(+148mn\) in 2026E. We believe this improving cash flow trajectory will allow the business to get closer to "self- funding" distributions to BN with limited (- \(1 - 2bn\) ) contribution from BN to support debt paydown through 2027E. Importantly, this improving cash flow dynamic is before the impact of property sales - which we believe will generate an incremental \(2bn\) of proceeds from monetization between 2026 and 2027E.
About \(25\%\) of the asset side of the BN balance sheet is comprised of Real Estate; BN

owns a \(\) 25bn\$ portfolio of direct investment properties ("Core" + "T&D") as well as \(\sim\) 6.5bn worth of stakes in BAM- managed BSREP funds (opportunistic real estate drawdown funds). On a reported basis, about \(>30\%\) of headline Distributable Earnings is derived from the Real Estate portfolio. In aggregate, we believe the underlying property metrics of this portfolio are relatively healthy vs. peer listed REITs, with strong occupancy trends and solid same- store- sales growth (especially in "Core" portfolio).

The "Core" portfolio is a combination of Office and Retail properties that are "Class A" with relatively healthy capital structures; most of these are properties that Brookfield will not sell, with only modest planned dispositions across the portfolio by 2029 in BN's target plan. By contrast, the T&D portfolio contains assets with higher leverage that are "fix and sell" rather than perpetual holdings; BN plans to monetize the entire T&D portfolio over time, with the vast majority expected to be monetized by 2029.

Net- net, we believe BN will increasingly right- size the aggregate \(\) 24.5bn\(of direct real estate properties in - line with its plan for\) \sim \$ 15bn in total RE equity by 2029. For the BSREP funds, there are currently outstanding commitments that BN will need to fund (most notably, \(\) 3bn\(in unfunded capital commitment to latest BAM - managed BSREP flagship fund), but ultimately we believe BN will let the majority of these assets roll - off as the funds are monetized. Including non - Real Estate managed funds that sit on the balance sheet, BN is targeting at\) \ \(8bn\) end- state by 2029 (vs. \(\) 11bn\(today).

We believe that a key concern for investors has been the book value that BN ascribes to the Real Estate portfolio on its balance sheet, and to that end we conduct a peer- based scenario analysis to estimate "fair value" of BN's real estate assets. Our analysis suggests \(40 - 60\%\) downside, or \(- \Phi 12bn\) of total equity vs. \(25bn\) book value of equity that BN currently assigns to the portfolio. Importantly, however, this \(12bn\) would suggest meaningful upside to current "market- implied" value of Real Estate at BN; our reverse- engineered SOTP analysis suggests the market is ascribing negative value to the portfolio (- \(12bn\) ).

Ultimately, the main input in Real Estate valuation models is the capitalization rate, which BN / BPG filings provide on a quarterly basis. Below we compare terminal cap rates used in BPG's valuation model against: (a) implied public REIT cap rates; (b) cap rates of aggregate transacted real estate properties (via RCA). Net- net, we find that BPY is utilizing cap rates and discount rates well below those of actual property transactions in 2024 (BPG is using higher valuation multiples vs. those of actual spot real estate transactions), as well as what the market is implying for the most relevant public REITs.

To double click into this dynamic, we attempt to quantify the delta between comparable listed REITs and BPG's portfolio - to better size the impact of MTM should comparable cap rates be used to value BN's real estate assets. While there are meaningful asset specific differences between BN's portfolio and publicly traded peers, we construct a "benchmark" of peer listed REITs to derive scenario cap rates using the comps. We focus on occupancy rates, NOI margins, NOI growth trends, leverage trends, and

geography where applicable to select the best comps. Our analysis suggests that peers similar to BN's Core portfolio trade at an implied cap rate in the range of \(5.5\% - 7.0\%\) ; BN's implied cap rate (our calculation, reported FV vs. NTM NOI) on the Core Portfolio is meaningfully lower at \(4.1\%\) . Similarly, we see properties akin to BN's T&D portfolio trading with an implied cap rate of \(6.0\% - 7.2\%\) vs. BN's \(5.4\%\) implied cap rate on its T&D portfolio. Based on these public comps, our illustrative analysis suggests that if valued alongside publicly traded REITs, BN's equity value in Core and T&D portfolios would be \(\sim 45\%\) below its carrying value or about \(\) 13bn\(vs.\) \ \(25bn\) carrying value).

While this is clearly a significant delta, we believe the market implied discount embedded in BN's market cap is significantly more punitive even relative to this conservative scenario. Based on a SOTP analysis, we think BN's current market cap implies - \(\) 4bn\(value. In other words, our \sim 45\%\) downside scenario suggests \~ \(\) 17bn\(of upside relative to what the market is implying today.\)

A key component to our thesis at BN is the embedded improvement in the underlying cash flows of the BPG holdings. The standalone BPG business has been generating negative cash flow since before 2022/2023, and has not covered the cash earnings (in the form of a dividend) that it pays to BN each quarter. We estimate that the portfolio generated - \(\) 187\\(mn in cash flow (FFO) during 2024; the annual dividend to BN is\) \ \(500mn\) . Over this period of time, BN has been using its own capital to pay down corporate level debt at the BPG portfolio - which while incrementally helpful in bridging to positive cash flows from the RE portfolio in the future, the contribution has been a drag on BN's aggregate capital generation; since 2023, we estimate that \(>\) 3bn of corporate BPG debt has been paid down by BN, accounting for \(>20\%\) of the \(\) 14bn\$ in total DE that BN generated in the same period. In 2Q25, the business flipped into positive territory (albeit only \(+\) 5mn of positive FFO), and we forecast - \(\) 74mn\$ in 2025E, and \(+\) 148mn in 2026E. We believe this improving cash flow trajectory will allow the business to get closer to "self-funding" with limited ( \(\sim\) 3bn) contribution from BN to support debt paydown through 2027E.

Core portfolio, and parts of the T&D portfolio at BN, operating metrics remain at least in- line with peer REITs, and in many cases parts of the business (Core portfolio) generate superior operating metrics. Specifically, same- store Net Operating Income (NOI) growth, occupancy trends, and NOI per sq ft all suggest relative health.
\(\) 2.6bn\(of interest expense across the portfolio, vs. the\) \ \(2.8bn\) of NOI generated in the same year.

3. We estimate \(60\%\) of total debt is floating rate: About \(60\%\) of the total debt at the BPG portfolio is floating rate, with the vast majority of this being property-level (non-recourse) debt. With policy rates expected to decline in the near-term, we see significant embedded operating leverage.

4. Disposition plan articulated and tracking in-line: BN has been successful so far in executing against its plan to sell down (a) a portion of the Core real estate portfolio; and more importantly (b) the vast majority of the T&D portfolio. In the T&D portfolio, we estimate that since 2023 BN has disposed of over \(\) 6bn\(of property fair value ( \sim 19\% ) of the total portfolio backbook). With\) \ \(26bn\) of FV today, BN plans to monetize substantially of this portfolio by 2029. This adds additional support to cash flow dynamics firmwide.

Across this analysis we focus on legacy BPY/BPG earnings - the property portfolio that previously was traded in public markets but has since been fully acquired by BN. Here, "BPG" refers to the Core + Transitional & Development Real Estate assets that sit directly on the BN balance sheet. We exclude the North American residential business that BN also owns and operates - this business is included in reported T&D cash flows metrics, but we exclude it from our analysis; the earnings are a function of large, lumpy, non-recurring lot sales and we intend to focus on recurring sources of cash.

As noted above, the Real Estate portfolio is currently generating negative "operating FFO" or funds from operation - which we believe is the best proxy for "cash earnings" in BN's reported Real Estate metrics. BN reports both NOI and FFO for its Core + T&D businesses. NOI, or "Net Operating Income" represents the recurring property-level earnings generated by the portfolio (before financing expenses, property-debt, etc.). FFO, or "Funds from Operations" represents the earnings to BN after it pays all associated interest expense (property-level and corporate level), as well as segment-level G&A expense and other items.

With \(\sim 60\%\) of total debt floating rate in nature, and with policy rates expected to move meaningfully lower in the next few years, we believe BPG can begin generating positive FFO by 2026 - without incremental property sales. That said, given that part of the BN plan is to monetize a portion of the Core portfolio and substantially all of the T&D portfolio by 2029, we see additional cash generation ( \(>\) 2bn across 2026/2027) from the monetization of these assets. Both the inflection in rates as well as the capital from properties sold will generate meaningful capital that BN can allocate to more efficient businesses firmwide, or else use to return capital to shareholders.

We expect that BN's Distributable Earnings and cash flows will be significantly enhanced over the next 2- 3 years as the firm begins to recognize Carried Interest / Performance fees on several large vintages. Our bottoms- up analysis of funds likely to generate carried interest in the near- term suggests that BN will see \(3.5bn\) of net realized carry through 4Q27; this compares to just \(1.2bn\) of carried interest generated to BN since 2023 (through 2Q25). As of 2Q25, the firm had about \(6.7bn\) in net accrued carry balances on the balance sheet, the bulk of which we believe is derived from BSREP II, BIF II, and Oaktree Opportunities X; we consider this the "inventory" of future performance fees.

BN current owns \(73\%\) of the Distributable Earnings generated by BAM; as part of the 2022 spin- out transaction, BN retained \(100\%\) of the carried interest that BAM was generating on pre- spin- out vintages. After using a portion to pay compensation, about \(67\%\) of the gross carried interest from these legacy funds will be allocated to BN shareholders. For vintages post spin- out, BN is entitled to \(33\%\) of the net carried interest; the portion dedicated to compensation will come out of BAM's share, so that BN's "stake" in carried interest is \(33\%\) of aggregate gross carried interest.

With a weak monetization backdrop in the last few years, realized carried interest has been running below historical monetization pace of \(\sim 13\%\) of beginning of period accrued balances. Between 2Q23 and 2Q25, BN saw \(\sim \$ 1bn\) of net realized carried interest, representing an \(8\%\) annualized monetization pace. While the weaker industry- wide realization backdrop is a main contributor to the slower balances, another factor is BN/BAM's fund structure which generally follows European Waterfall style carried interest recognition, whereby fund LPs need to have their invested capital + a preferred return fully returned before the GP can take carry/performance fees. This creates a delay in carry recognition even as funds begin to monetize assets.

With that in mind, our fund- by- fund analysis suggests that a handful of larger vintages are approaching the LP capital return threshold for BN to start taking realized carried interest. Specifically, we believe that BSREP II (Opportunistic Real Estate), BIF II (Infrastructure), and Oaktree Opportunities X (Opportunistic Credit) will start generating realized carry to BN with total net potential fees of \(\sim \$ 1.7bn\) across the three funds, by our estimate.

In order to value BN's carry/performance fee opportunity set we considered a three- step approach to estimate present value of future performance fees. Since the firm's economics in future funds will differ from legacy funds, our fair value of BN's carry consists of:

Present Value of Future (Un- Generated) Carry from In- the- Ground Investments: For funds that are early in their lives / expected investment period, there is little generated and accrued carried interest given that BAM is still in the process to putting capital to work. For this capital, we can extrapolate a future expected carry

estimate by estimating how much longer we expect the fund to be "live" (remaining investment period + harvest period) based on a 9- year total fund life. We add strategy- specific implied target quarterly return to the remaining "live years". Importantly, we look at fund balances excluding estimate BAM/BN stake within those funds, as the GP / associate capital does not earn or generate carry. We tackle each vintage individually given the differing ownership structures (BN entitled to varying % of net realized balances post- BAM spin- out). Our analysis suggests that current "in- the- ground" investments will generate \(\) 100bn\(in aggregate incremental fair value as total funds reach maturity. The weighted average remaining life of these funds is 5.3 years; in aggregate these vintages would generate\) \ \(18bn\) of carried interest on a gross basis, or \(\) 9bn\(to BN. We apply a\) 13\% \(discount rate to these expected cash flows (informed by our estimated growth rates for carry), to arrive at\) \ \(4.7bn\) of present fair value. We show this math in Exhibit 66.

Future Carry from Uninvested Capital: Importantly, BAM also has \(\) 128bn\(of "uncalled capital commitments" - uninvested capital that is sitting in drawdown funds that are even earlier in their fund lives. Using segment specific target MOIC returns, we estimate future fair value gains that BN could derive from this uninvested capital. We use segment- specific carry rates to estimate total gross carry generation potential; in the go- forward period, BN's share of future carry is 33%. Given that this is uninvested capital, we assume it will take \~9 years for this carry to be generated and monetized by BN. As we show in Exhibit 67, we apply the same 13% discount rate to this future expected cash flow and we find\) \ \(1.7bn\) of present fair value of carry expected from uninvested capital.

Current Accrued Carry Balances: Finally, we calculate the present value of carry balances that are currently generated and sit on the BN balance sheet today. As of 2Q25, these amounted to \(\) 6.7bn\(net, at BN's share. We know that BN anticipates\) \sim \(3.4bn\) of this net unrealized carry to monetize over the next three years; we assume the remaining balance will be realized over an \~8 year window. We take those two buckets separately given the different timelines, and we discount them back at\) 13\% \(. Net combined as shown in Exhibit 68, we find the\) \ \(6.7bn\) accrual balance on the B/S is worth \(\) 3.6bn\(on a present value basis.

Summing up the three components (Exhibit 69, we estimate BN's fair value of carry is \(\) 8.6bn\(after tax (assuming\) 15\% \(tax rate). As a sanity check, assuming the firm's \~\) 6.7bn in net accrued carry gets recognized over 5 years, the implied multiple of our fair value analysis is\) 7.5X \(on a "P/E" basis) on BN's normalized annual performance fee / carry earnings - consistent with how the market generally views Alt Managers' carry valuation.

BWS (Brookfield Wealth Solutions) is BN's wholly owned Insurance company, and a critical part of the firm's growth strategy via its symbiotic relationship with BAM (Brookfield Asset Management) - a structure pioneered by Apollo/Athene, with many other Alternative Managers pursuing various flavors of the same strategy. The business accounts for about \(25\%\) of BN's total distributable earnings as of 2Q. Through several large acquisitions, today, BWS is a scaled player in the insurance space with \(\)102bn\(in net reserves - primarily concentrated in Fixed Annuities ( \sim 80\% of the book). We expect the business to grow assets at \sim 14\% CAGR through 2027 with \sim 10\% (net) annualized organic growth via continued market share gains in the US retail annuities channel, expansion into U.S. and non - U.S. PRT (Pension Risk Transfer) market, and through funding agreement issuance. The firm also houses a relatively small P&C business, which could become a larger source of growth overtime - though not part of our base case. Management is targeting a 15\% ROE for the business, though we think industry spread compression and lower U.S. policy rates pose a modest risk to these targets (we model net spread in the 160- 170bps range vs. management's \sim 180- 200bps target).

That said, we think BWS comes with several unique attributes including: (1) Greater exposure to Alternative investments, leveraging BAM's expertise and allowing the firm to earn premium investment rates; (2) Relatively lower leverage and meaningful amount of excess capital vs. peers; and (3) Global footprint and scale with large financial institutions, enabling the firm accelerate its pace of sales. Combined, we think BWS can sustain \~14%- 15% ROE through 2027 (a bit lower than management's 15% target), with a 14% CAGR in distributable earnings.

BWS is a \(\) 102bn\$ insurance business, with Indexed annuities comprising the largest part of the liability stack at over \(60\%\) . We expect BWS reserves to grow at a \(14\%\) CAGR through 2027 driven by: (1) Market share gains in the US fixed annuities channel; (2) expansion into the PRT market; and (3) supplemental growth from Funding Agreements. Specifically, BWS delivered a \(7.4\%\) in net organic growth (net flows) in 2024 (23% gross asset flow rate offset by \(\sim 15\%\) in outflows, with one- time headwinds around the timing of the AEL acquisition) or \(\) 6.2bn\(of net assets ( \sim\) 19bn gross). So far in 2025, 1H25 annualized net new asset rate is running at \(75\%\) , which we expect to accelerate into 2H, resulting in \(\) 18bn\(of gross inflows for the year. Management is targeting roughly\) \ \(20bn -\) 25bn in gross annuity sales annually - largely through gaining additional share in the Fixed Annuities market in the U.S., but also by growing share of the Pension Risk Transfer (PRT) market, and via Funding Agreements (these latter two are "Institutional Annuities"). The firm has also recently expanded into the U.K. market, with the pending acquisition of Just Group, creating another avenue of growth for the business; Just Group is one of 10 major players in the U.K. PRT market, with a \~\) 40bn asset portfolio (note, the deal is not included in our projection / expected to close by the end of 2025/early 2026).

Overall, we expect the aggregate annuity business at BWS will deliver a \(9\%\) net organic growth rate in 2025 ( \(\sim\) 8bn net issuance), followed by \(10\% - 11\%\) in both 2026 ( \(\sim\) 11bn), and 2027 ( \(\sim\) 12bn). This includes \(\) 18bn\$ in gross sales in 2025, \(\) 21bn\$ in 2026 and \(\) 23bn\$ in 2027, with retail contributing \(\) 13- 15bn\$ in annual gross

sales on average and institutional channel contributing \(\) 5- 8bn\$ in gross sales. We expect BWS' growth to be a function of compelling secular demand for guaranteed income in the individual channel, expanding opportunities outside the U.S., and the firm's ability to deliver attractive policy rates by leveraging its investment expertise via BAM (Brookfield Asset Management). In addition, we think Brookfield's multi- faceted network and scale with large financial institutions will play a role in their ability to gain share - particularity in the individual U.S. market. Internationally, we think there could be increased organic growth opportunities in the UK market on the back of the recently announced Just Group acquisition, as well as potential expansion into the P&C market - both currently not contemplated in our model.
We discuss industry dynamics and BWS competitive position within each of its key growth markets below.

The fixed annuity market stands at \(\) 1.35\(trillion in assets, compounding at an 8% CAGR since 2020. The combination of higher interest rates and demographic shifts resulted in the industry seeing record annual volumes in 2024 with over\) \ \(300bn\) of gross new sales; preliminary data for 1H25 suggests \(\) 143bn\(in gross sales - on pace with 2024 full year levels. Net of outflows, the fixed annuity industry is growing at - 7% annualized net flow rate over the last several quarters, with an uptick in redemptions likely a function of policyholders seeking to rotate into now - higher yielding products towards year - end 2024. Fixed Indexed Annuities comprise about 40% of industry annual sales volumes, while fixed deferred annuities are - 50%.

Looking ahead, LIMRA forecasts \(\) 90- 100bn\(of Fixed Indexed sales volumes annually through 2027, vs. the\) \ \(127bn\) seen in 2024; for Fixed Deferred annuities, LIMRA expects \(\) 115- 130bn\(each year (vs.\) \ \(150bn\) in 2024). The forecast was predicated on January 2025 expectations for policy rates, which ended up being higher so far than originally anticipated. As a result, 2025 sales volumes for the industry are running ahead of this original forecast. Although we expect industry gross sales to moderate, our regression analysis of sales volumes vs. both policy rates \(+\) S&P500 levels suggests a more modest decline for both buckets. We estimate \(\) 110\(bn in annual industry Fixed Index Annuity sales through 2027 and about\) \ \(150bn\) per year for Fixed Deferred Annuities. Combined, we see - \(\) 260bn\(in industry gross sales - below 2023 and 2024 record levels of -\) \ \(300bn\) , but still robust by historical standards.

BWS current runs with a low- single digit \((3 - 4\%)\) market share of the Fixed Deferred Annuity market in the U.S., and our analysis suggests market share on a pro forma basis (as if they owned AEL, American National, etc. since inception) in this bucket has been flat for a few years. In Fixed Indexed Annuities, BWS has a higher market share - in the \(7\%\) range. The FIA channel is likely to be a larger focus of growth for the firm. For

context, in the FIA channel, both Athene and Allianz have had a \(10 - 14\%\) market share each, Corebridge has been in the \(7 - 9\%\) range, while Global Atlantic has been in the \(4 - 6\%\) market share range.

We expect BWS's market share in the Fixed Deferred Annuity market to remain relatively range- bound in the \(3\% - 4\%\) zone, while in the Fixed Index Annuities, we expect market share to expand marginally, approaching \(8\%\) by 2027. We think BWS's market share opportunity set is driven by (1) Attractive rates - particularly in the longer- end of the market, where BWS can leverage BAM investment expertise in longer- duration strategies to offer clients a premium rate/higher premium bonus in the first year and (2) Expansion into the bank distribution channel, where BWS has a lower footprint relative to some of its larger competitors such as Athene/Apollo.

With retail annuities being a relatively commoditized product, we think the main considerations for an annuity buyer will be the credit quality of the originator and the crediting rate of the product. Customer service / sales support clearly plays a role, but this is more difficult to assess objectively. Our analysis of current product offerings shows that BWS will toggle the crediting rate it offers to new buyers; however, the firm is typically 25- 50bps below the top- end of the range, with management noting that absent a strong need to grow the balance sheet, it would rather take moderate growth with lower liability costs. Rather than compete on crediting rates, we note that the BWS offerings will often carry a high "first year guaranteed yield", with a lofty premium bonus offered to buyers. For example, a \(10,000\) annuity purchase (the premium) with an \(11\%\) premium bonus suggests that the buyer would receive an incremental \(\) 1,100\(that is credited to his or her annuity value in year 1, subject to certain conditions (withdrawal / surrender commitments, etc.). This\) 11\% \(credit, coupled with a fixed yield of\) 3\% \(would imply a guaranteed first- year yield of\) 14\% \(; the headline crediting rate for the annuity is\) 3\% \(. We show this example (based on an actual 7- Yr American National Fixed Indexed Annuity offered by BWS) in Exhibit 94. Importantly, the premium bonus is considered part of an insurance company's "deferred acquisition cost", which is amortized over the life of the product; it is not part of the reported "cost of funds" and utilizing premium bonuses is a way to preserve reported net spread. We believe that using this model, BWS has ample room to toggle headline crediting rates higher without being a "price setter" when it wishes to take market share.

Additionally, we highlight BWS's relative under- penetration of the Bank channel; as of 2023 (latest available channel data), pro forma sales data from BWS shows that the firm only had a \(1\%\) market share for all annuities sold in the Wirehouse / Bank channel. Athene was capturing \(22\%\) market share that year, while Global Atlantic was capturing \(6\%\) (Exhibit 98). In aggregate, almost 1/4 of total annuity sales are via the Bank channel. BN/BWS believe that it can dramatically expand Wirehouse market share, given that BAM has strong existing distribution relationships with the largest banks in the US, whereas AEL was under- exposed to the channel, relying more heavily on Independent Agents.

Outside of Retail Annuities, BWS has started to expand its activities in the institutional market, both in the Pension Risk Transfer space ("PRT") and Funding Agreements ("FABNs"). We believe the institutional channel can add about \(3.9bn - 6.5bn\) in annual gross sales to BWS. A few notables include:

US PRT Market: US PRT market has experienced a rising pace of activity with average annualized pension buy- out / buy- in volumes of \(\) 50bn\(annually\) \ \(12bn\) per quarter) in recent quarters in the U.S. (Exhibit 100), representing bulk pension plans for sale; the annualized pace during the 2019- 2020 period was closer to \(- \Phi 30bn\) \((\) 7bn / quarter). BWS has captured \(- 6\%\) market share in the U.S. market on average since 2023 (Exhibit 101), which at the current pace implies \(- \Phi 3bn\) in annual transaction volume to BN.

UK PRT Market: More recently, BN obtained a license to participate in the U.K. PRT market where annual transaction volumes are currently running at \(>\) 30bn USD (Exhibit 102); in the U.K. market share is more concentrated with \(

Funding Agreements, or "FABNs" are essentially an annuity product that an institutional investor (endowment, pension, other large asset owners) can purchase. FABNs and similar products are unregistered and will typically offer a higher interest rate relative to equivalent cash products or "money market - like" alternative products. The market for FABNs has grown in recent years (see Exhibit 104) as insurance companies have sought diversified sources of liability growth, while institutional investors look to lock in above- market yields before rates come in. BN issued its first FABN in 1Q25 at \(\) 500\\(mn, and issued\)\\(400\\)mn in 2Q.

BWS's net spreads have been running at \(>200\) bps in aggregate, but about 180bps is on the firm's annuity portfolio (including both retail and institutional channels); \(>90\%\) of the book is the annuity business, the primary source of forward growth. The firm is aiming to maintain or expand the \(\sim 180\) bps spread in annuities over time. Notably, the firm's spreads on the annuity book has been compressing modestly from \(>200\) bps to about 175bps in 2Q25 amid tightening industry credit spreads and meaningful competition for fixed annuity sales. That said, the 175bps- 180bps range in 1H25 is still running above closest peers (ATH/APO and G.A./KKR), which were in 140- 150bps range in 1H25. Part of the BWS' relative premium comes from higher overall earning yields \((>5.7\%\) in 1H25) vs. ATH at around \(5.2\%\) and G.A. at \(4.65\% - 4.75\%\) range; BWS has relatively higher asset allocation to Alternative strategies. Given tight industry credit spreads, continued competitive pressures, and prospects of lower interest rates, we expect BWS spreads to see modest compression over the next 12- 18 months, bottoming in the 160bps range, before improving back toward the firm's most recent range of \(\sim 180\) bps. In our view this could weigh somewhat on the firm's \(15\%\) ROE target, but we think BWS's differentiated investment capabilities and relatively lower leverage levels should sustain the segment's ROE in the \(\sim 14 - 15\%\) range through 2027.

Relative to peers, a greater portion of BWS's Investment Portfolio is in "alternative" investments (Private Real Estate, Alt Funds, etc.), with an \(11\%\) allocation vs. \(8\%\) for Global Atlantic and \(5\%\) for Athene. The relatively higher allocation to Alts has enabled a higher yield on Invested Assets with BWS generating \(5.8\%\) as of 1Q25 (on its standalone annuities book); this is about \(\sim 70\) bps above ATH and \(\sim 100\) bps above GA in the same period. BWS has been leaning into the strategic relationship with BAM, as the business has been deploying capital into high- single digit yielding investments over the last 2 years that are originated and managed by Brookfield Asset Management (Exhibit 110); "new deployment" as reported by BWS has been into investments that are yielding \(8 - 11\%\) .

The Alts Portfolio at BWS is a combination of BAM Real Estate Funds (BSREP), direct RE assets (including some "Core" properties migrated from the BN B/S), and BAM- managed Infra funds among others (Exhibit 113). Within that bucket, about \(40\%\) of the Real Estate assets (RE Partnerships + Investment RE) are exposed to Office properties; about \(1 / 4\) is exposed to Single Family Residential properties. We estimate an average yield generated by the Alts portfolio by comparing the GAAP metrics that BWS files as a standalone insurance entity to the non- GAAP metrics that BN reports. We believe the portfolio has generated an average yield of \(10\%\) over the last 18 months (Exhibit 111 and Exhibit 112).

We apply a two- pronged approach to value BN with a 50/50 weight consisting of: (1) SOTP analysis of BN's business components to account for multiple business lines of the BN conglomerate and (2) ROE- informed P/B valuation methodology of the entire enterprise to account for the improving ROE and capital compounding nature of the business. Our SOTP analysis implies an \(82 12\) - month value, while the ROE- informed P/B framework suggests a \(74 12\) - month value or on a target P/B of 2.3X (on 2026 BVPS). With a 50/50 mix, our 12- month price target is \(78 - or\) an implied 2026 P/E of 17.3X and P/B of 2.6X (for shares of BN.TO, we estimate a\)107 target price based on spot FX rate of 1.37). For context, BN shares currently trade at 14.5X 2026 P/E - this compares to a \(\sim 19X\) multiple for the closest Alternative Managers' peers (APO and KKR). BN's current P/B (on 2Q25 BVPS) is 2.3X, which compares to 3.3X P/B for APO and KKR.

Our blended target price implies a target P/B multiple of 2.6X, which is 0.7X discount to APO / KKR; on total P/E (2026) our target implies 17.3X, also a discount to spot APO/KKR P/E multiples at 19X. We believe this is warranted given the earnings mix of the three firms. As we show in Exhibit 117, BN has less FRE exposure than both names, which is considered to be the highest multiple earnings stream in our Alts coverage - well below KKR's \(\sim 55\%\) FRE mix, and also below APO's \(40\%\) . That said, when accounting for carried interest and earnings from B/S holdings, BN's mix skews more towards Alts than does APO (where insurance earnings at \(\sim 50\%\) of segment earnings). Additional considerations include BN's direct exposure to Real Estate assets owned on the balance sheet. Net- net, we think BN's composition implies an overall premium to APO's multiple, but likely a discount to KKR's.

BN's pro rata ownership in the business. BN currently owns \(\sim 73\%\) of BAM's total equity. On a per share basis (to BN shareholders), our BAM target price is worth \(\) 50.97\(per BN share.

Insurance: We apply a 9.0X multiple to BN's Insurance business, which is a premium to the 8.0X we use for both APO's ATH business, and KKR's G.A. in our respective SOTP for both names. So far, BN has been able to maintain better gross and net spreads given a higher allocation of the portfolio to Alts. Our multiple suggests the Insurance business is worth \(\) 18.4bn\(or\) \ \(12.10\) per share.

Carried Interest: Our per share estimate of carried interest fair value is discussed above in Exhibit 69. We use a DCF on a segment basis, as well as for various types of carried interest (in- the- ground vs. undeployed) to generate a present value. Our valuation infers \(\) 8.6bn\(of present value of carried interest, which implies a\) 7.5X multiple on annualized, after- tax net carried interest to BN, in- line with peer Alt Managers.

Real Estate: In our SOTP, we use our benchmark- implied Real Estate valuation discussed above in Exhibit 29 and Exhibit 28. We are using a blended cap rate of \(5.5\%\) across the aggregate Core + T&D portfolios, which implies meaningful downside to the \(4 - 5\%\) cap rates that BN is currently valuing the assets at. Our \(\sim\) \(13bn\) estimate for BN's Real Estate equity ( \(8.33\) per share) is a \(\sim 45\%\) discount to the value on the BN B/S.

Balance Sheet: For the shares of BIP, BEP, and BBU that sit on the BN B/S, we take current market value, less a \(10\%\) liquidity discount; we believe the value of the shares would be well below current valuation if a situation arose whereby BN would sell those shares. We also apply a \(10\%\) liquidity discount to the \(\sim\) \(11bn\) of equity that BN owns of BAM- managed funds / co- investments. After accounting for debt ( \(19bn\) of debt recourse to BN), we derive a \(\sim\) \(5.32\) per share value of the BN B/S.
Our standalone SOTP methodology ( \(50\%\) of our final Target Price) implies a per share price for BN of \(\) 82\$ .

In addition to the SOTP methodology, we also consider BN's overall ROE / P- to- Book approach in evaluating how the enterprise performs as a whole. We considered P/B multiples across Financials including Insurance companies (EQH, PRU, CRBG, MET) and Alternative Asset Managers with larger balances sheets (APO and KKR) relative to their respective ROEs to come up with an "ROE multiplier" - how much the market is paying per unit of ROE. We then applied a mix of these multiples to BN's ROE based on its earnings mix.

Specifically, across the Insurance companies in our analysis, we find an average ROE multiplier of 7.3X. Across the Alts in the data set, we find a much higher multiplier at 18.4X. Given BN's earnings mix (shown in Exhibit 122), we derive a 15.7X ROE multiplier; when we apply this to our estimated 2026 ROE of \(14.9\%\) , we arrive at a 2026E P/BVPS multiple of 2.3X.
We are modeling a \(\) 31.4\(BVPS in 2026E, which net - net implies a\) \ \(74\) ROE- informed valuation ( \(50\%\) of our final Target Price on BN).

Interest rate path deviates from our base case: Our thesis assumes lower policy rates (using current Forward Curve assumptions as inputs) that help BPG's largely floating- rate debt burden and support real estate cash flow inflection by 2026. If rates stay higher for longer or rise, BPG interest expense would remain elevated, delaying FFO improvement, and likely increasing BN's capital injections, which would reduce funds available for shareholder return.

Insurance spread compression and sales momentum risk at BWS amid rising competition: Our model assumes BWS net spreads normalize around \(\sim 160-\) 180bps. Tighter credit spreads on investments, and/or more aggressive competitor crediting rates / higher BWS cost of funds could compress spreads and ROE. In addition, slower progress expanding bank/wirehouse distribution or weaker retail/PRT/FABN volumes would reduce the \(\sim 14\%\) DE CAGR we forecast.

Asset management fundraising/deployment below expectations: Given BN's \(73\%\) ownership of BAM, weaker LP demand or slower capital deployment/management fee activation would dampen BAM earnings to BN. This would also impact our carried interest DCF, which assumes steady execution against the uncalled capital commitments at BAM.

Real estate valuation and liquidity prove weaker than expected: Our SOTP already applies materially higher cap rates than BN's carrying values and implies \(50\%\) downside to reported equity in Core/T&D. That said, a harsher transaction market, lower NOI, or slower asset sales could push fair value below our estimate, limit planned deleveraging, and reduce disposition proceeds we include in gross cash flows.

Carry realization timing and magnitude fall short: Our thesis includes a step- up in net realized carried interest beginning in 2026. A prolonged exit slowdown, weaker fund performance, or delays in reaching European waterfall hurdles would reduce realized carry, lowering capital- light cash flows and ROE.

Regulatory and rating risks, particularly at BWS: Changes in insurance capital regimes, investment eligibility for insurers, or adverse rating actions could limit BWS's ability to originate annuities at target economics, increase capital needs, or raise funding costs. Additionally, if mix shift of investment portfolio into more equity / real estate proves to be more capital consumptive, the "self- funding" nature of the business may prove overly optimistic, requiring BN to inject equity / increase reserves.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our groups, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.
